function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Significant research gaps in understanding the association of built environment (BE) attributes with the spread of COVID-19.","Impact":"Ineffective identification of clusters and mechanisms of infections, leading to delayed or ineffective control measures for the pandemic.","Mitigation":"Conduct comprehensive studies to fill the research gaps, improve analysis approaches, and address spatial heterogeneity. Use scientific methodologies to inform policy-making against future pandemics.","Technologies":"Data analytics, spatial modeling, and advanced research methodologies for epidemiological studies.","People":"Public health researchers, epidemiologists, policymakers, urban planners, and healthcare professionals.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health agencies, and government bodies."},{"Description":"Lack of understanding of the direct and indirect face-to-face communication reflected by the built environment (BE).","Impact":"Difficulty in identifying and managing high-risk areas for disease transmission, leading to potential increases in the spread of COVID-19 and future pandemics.","Mitigation":"Conduct studies to evaluate the role of the built environment in facilitating or hindering face-to-face communication. Implement measures to improve ventilation, spacing, and sanitation in built environments.","Technologies":"Sensors for monitoring air quality and ventilation, crowd flow analysis, and architectural design for spatial distancing.","People":"Architects, urban designers, public health experts, and building managers.","Owner":"Architectural firms, urban planning agencies, and public health organizations."},{"Description":"Risks associated with international attention on epidemic analysis, policy measures, and global development based on responses in China.","Impact":"Potential adoption of ineffective or misaligned strategies based on limited or biased understanding of China's responses to the COVID-19 pandemic.","Mitigation":"Encourage multi-disciplinary studies and information-sharing to provide a holistic understanding of China's responses. Collaborate with international partners to leverage diverse perspectives and expertise in pandemic response and policy development.","Technologies":"International data sharing platforms, collaborative research networks, and cross-cultural communication tools.","People":"Global health researchers, policy analysts, international relations experts, and public health officials.","Owner":"International health organizations, research consortiums, and global health policy institutions."}]}
